segments.en: And today we are going back in time again, and this time we're going to be in the 1960s.
segments.cn: 今天我们将再次回到过去，这次我们要回到1960年代。

segments.en: We're going to learn some phrases and some slang that were really popular back in 1964.
segments.cn: 我们将学习一些在1964年非常流行的短语和俚语。

segments.en: And most of these phrases and words we still use today, so it's very interesting and very good to know.
segments.cn: 这些短语和单词我们今天仍然在使用，所以了解它们非常有趣且重要。

segments.en: I'm looking forward to this trip back in time, so why don't we get started with the dialogue?
segments.cn: 我期待这次时光之旅，为什么不开始对话呢？
我真的很喜欢你的地方。

segments.en: Those lava lamps are far out.
Thanks for letting me crash here tonight.
segments.cn: 谢谢你今晚让我住在这里。

segments.en: I wanted a pad where people could come, listen to music, and just hang loose.
segments.cn: 我想要一个人们可以来、听音乐、放松的地方。

segments.en: We should throw a bash here and make it a really happening scene.
segments.cn: 我们应该在这里举办一个派对，让它成为一个真正热闹的场景。

segments.en: Hey, I got a split for a while.
Are you okay here by yourself?
segments.cn: 你一个人在这里还好吗？

segments.en: You can take care of your business.
segments.cn: 你可以去处理你的事情。

segments.en: The music, the mood, and the words, right?
So why don't we get down to business and look at the vocabulary that we saw in this dialogue in Language Takeaway.
segments.cn: 那么我们为什么不开始看看在这段对话中看到的词汇呢？

segments.en: Well, the dialogue opened, and we heard this guy say, hey, man, I really like your pad.
segments.cn: 好吧，对话开始时，我们听到这个家伙说，嘿，兄弟，我真的很喜欢你的地方。
我真的很喜欢你的地方。

segments.en: Okay, so pad, a very informal way of saying?
segments.cn: 好吧，地方是一个非常非正式的说法？

segments.en: And now you can still use it today.
segments.cn: 现在你今天仍然可以使用它。

segments.en: We often hear the expression bachelor pad.
segments.cn: 我们经常听到“单身公寓”这个表达。

segments.en: So that's an apartment where a single man lives.
segments.cn: 所以这是一个单身男人居住的公寓。

segments.en: Usually it's very nicely decorated and really a nice apartment, right?
segments.cn: 通常装饰得很好，真的是一个不错的公寓，对吧？

segments.en: Or maybe it has empty pizza boxes all over the floor, Marco.
segments.cn: 或者可能地上满是空的比萨盒，Marco。

segments.en: But so that's what pad means, an apartment.
segments.cn: 所以这就是“地方”的意思，一个公寓。

segments.en: They were talking about the apartment, and he said the lava lamps are far out.
segments.cn: 他们在谈论公寓，他说熔岩灯真酷。

segments.en: So that's really cool or amazing.
segments.cn: 所以这真的很酷或惊人。

segments.en: And now lava lamps, those are those strange cone-looking lamps, right?
segments.cn: 现在熔岩灯，那些是那些奇怪的锥形灯，对吧？

segments.en: Kind of a light with like some liquid moving inside.
segments.cn: 有点像里面有液体流动的灯。

segments.en: Yeah, we'll post some pictures of that.
segments.cn: 是的，我们会发布一些照片。

segments.en: And the lamps are far out.
So now you can use that with other things, right?
segments.cn: 所以现在你可以用在其他事物上，对吧？

segments.en: Like you are really far out.
Yeah, or this music is really far out.
segments.cn: 是的，或者这音乐真的很酷。

segments.en: It kind of gives you the feeling like it's sort of spacey.
segments.cn: 它给你一种太空的感觉。

segments.en: So the pad is really far out.
segments.cn: 所以这个地方真的很酷。

segments.en: And he was saying, thanks for letting me crash here tonight.
segments.cn: 他在说，谢谢你今晚让我住在这里。

segments.en: So to crash at someone's place.
segments.cn: 所以在某人的地方暂住。

segments.en: So we're not talking about like a car crash here.
segments.cn: 所以我们不是在谈论汽车碰撞。

segments.en: So when you crash somewhere, what do you do?
segments.cn: 所以当你在某个地方暂住时，你在做什么？

segments.en: Well, you are staying there, then you're going to stay there as a guest.
segments.cn: 嗯，你在那里待着，作为客人。

segments.en: So if for example, you're going to New York and you're going to visit a friend, you might crash at your friend's house.
segments.cn: 所以例如，如果你要去纽约，去拜访朋友，你可能会在朋友家暂住。
所以这是一个有趣的词。

segments.en: And it is quite commonly used now.
So why don't we hear some examples of how we can use it.
segments.cn: 那么我们为什么不听听一些例子，看看我们如何使用它。

segments.en: Hey, man, can I crash at your place tonight?
segments.cn: 嘿，兄弟，我今晚可以在你家暂住吗？

segments.en: So I'm crashing at my girlfriend's house.
segments.cn: 所以我在我女朋友家暂住。

segments.en: No, you've been sleeping on my couch for a month.
segments.cn: 不，你已经在我沙发上睡了一个月。

segments.en: You're not going to crash here tonight.
segments.cn: 你今晚不会在这里崩溃。

segments.en: So again, this means like great or cool or really nice.
segments.cn: 所以再次，这意味着很棒或很酷或真的很好。

segments.en: Yeah, this is I think this is one of the main words of the 1960s.
segments.cn: 是的，我认为这是1960年代的主要词汇之一。

segments.en: So it kind of gives you the sense that it's sort of really cool, but in a relaxed way.
segments.cn: 所以这给你一种感觉，真的很酷，但又很放松。

segments.en: And finally his friend, he said, hey, I got a split for a while.
segments.cn: 最后他的朋友说，嘿，我要分开一会儿。

segments.en: Okay, so if I say I have to split.
segments.cn: 好的，如果我说我得分开。

segments.en: And it means I have to leave for a little bit.
segments.cn: 这意味着我得离开一小会儿。

segments.en: You may not have heard this one before.
segments.cn: 你可能以前没听过这个。

segments.en: So why don't we hear some examples to help you understand how it's used.
segments.cn: 那么我们来听一些例子，帮助你理解它是如何使用的。

segments.en: We've got a split before the police get here.
segments.cn: 我们得在警察到这里之前分开。

segments.en: I have to wake up early tomorrow.
Now also, I think you can use it for relationships, right?
segments.cn: 现在，我认为你也可以用它来形容关系，对吧？
所以你结束了你的关系。

segments.en: Okay, so we saw five really common phrases from the 1960s.
segments.cn: 好的，所以我们看到了五个1960年代非常常见的短语。

segments.en: Let's listen to the dialogue again a little bit slower.
segments.cn: 让我们再慢一点听对话。

segments.en: And then we'll come back and look at some phrases from the 60s.
segments.cn: 然后我们再回来看看一些60年代的短语。

segments.en: Hey, man, I really like your pad.
segments.cn: 嘿，兄弟，我真的很喜欢你的地方。

segments.en: Those lava lamps are far out.
Thanks for letting me crash here tonight.
segments.cn: 谢谢你让我今晚在这里休息。

segments.en: I wanted a pad where people could come listen to music and just hang loose.
segments.cn: 我想要一个人们可以来听音乐和放松的地方。

segments.en: We could throw a bash here and make it a really happening scene.
segments.cn: 我们可以在这里举办一个派对，让它成为一个真正热闹的场景。

segments.en: Yeah, man, that would be groovy.
Hey, I got a split for a while.
Are you okay here by yourself?
segments.cn: 你一个人在这里还好吗？

segments.en: You go take care of your business.
Well, I want to get started at looking at these 1960s slang phrases.
segments.cn: 好吧，我想开始看看这些1960年代的俚语短语。

segments.en: So let's go now with putting it together.
segments.cn: 所以现在让我们开始整合。

segments.en: All right, I'm putting it together today.
Let's start with the first part.
segments.cn: 让我们从第一部分开始。

segments.en: He talked about you dig what I'm saying.
segments.cn: 他说你明白我在说什么。

segments.en: So we know the verb dig, which means to make a hole, right?
segments.cn: 所以我们知道动词dig，意思是挖一个洞，对吧？

segments.en: Yeah, but now he's talking about understand.
segments.cn: 是的，但现在他在说理解。

segments.en: Yeah, basically you dig what I'm saying.
segments.cn: 是的，基本上你明白我在说什么。

segments.en: Do you understand what I'm saying?
And when he says I dig it, he says I understand.
segments.cn: 当他说我明白时，他说我理解。

segments.en: Now there's also another meaning to this right apart from understand.
segments.cn: 现在除了理解之外，这还有另一个意思。

segments.en: Yeah, it can also mean I like it.
segments.cn: 是的，它也可以意味着我喜欢。

segments.en: Okay, so I really dig this type of music or I really dig this restaurant.
segments.cn: 好的，所以我真的很喜欢这种音乐或我真的很喜欢这家餐厅。

segments.en: Okay, so it's kind of I like it.
segments.cn: 好的，所以这有点像我喜欢。

segments.en: He said we could throw a bash here.
segments.cn: 他说我们可以在这里举办一个派对。

segments.en: So first of all, what is a bash?
Now I want to look at this verb to throw something.
segments.cn: 现在我想看看这个动词举办。

segments.en: So we know that you throw a ball, right?
segments.cn: 所以我们知道你可以扔一个球，对吧？

segments.en: But how can you throw a party?
segments.cn: 但你怎么能举办一个派对呢？

segments.en: Well, it's basically saying you organize or you host a party.
segments.cn: 嗯，这基本上是说你组织或主持一个派对。

segments.en: Okay, and how can you use this phrase?
segments.cn: 好的，你怎么能使用这个短语？

segments.en: Okay, so I can say last week I threw a birthday party in my house.
segments.cn: 好的，我可以说上周我在家举办了一个生日派对。

segments.en: Okay, or let's throw a bash to celebrate your engagement.
segments.cn: 好的，或者我们来举办一个派对庆祝你的订婚。

segments.en: Okay, or next week I'm going to throw a dinner party at my house.
segments.cn: 好的，或者下周我将在家举办一个晚宴派对。

segments.en: Okay, so to throw a party and it's usually used for for parties, right?
segments.cn: 好的，所以举办派对通常是用于派对，对吧？

segments.en: You wouldn't throw a... throw a meeting.
segments.cn: 你不会举办一个……召开会议。

segments.en: So now we heard them use the word man a lot, right?
segments.cn: 现在我们听到他们经常使用“man”这个词，对吧？

segments.en: Now, this is so common even in modern English that I think we need some examples.
segments.cn: 现在，这在现代英语中是如此常见，我认为我们需要一些例子。

segments.en: Hey, man, watch where you're going.
segments.cn: 嘿，兄弟，注意你走的地方。

segments.en: Yeah, man, that's a great idea.
segments.cn: 是的，兄弟，这是个好主意。

segments.en: So man is one of those words that you just use at the end of your sentences or the beginning or the beginning anywhere.
segments.cn: 所以“man”是一个你可以在句子的末尾或开头使用的词。

segments.en: And so you say hey man or yeah man.
segments.cn: 所以你可以说嘿，兄弟，或者是是的，兄弟。

segments.en: Yeah, but what about do you have to be a man to use it or do you have to be talking to a man to use it?
segments.cn: 是的，但你必须是个男人才能使用它吗？或者你必须和一个男人说话才能使用它吗？

segments.en: Men and women use the word man.
segments.cn: 男人和女人都使用“man”这个词。

segments.en: Yeah, and you can call a girl like hey man, how are you?
segments.cn: 是的，你可以对一个女孩说嘿，兄弟，你好吗？

segments.en: Yeah, but that sort of means that she's a really really good friend like the same level of friend as your guy friend.
segments.cn: 是的，但这意味着她是一个非常好的朋友，和你的男性朋友在同一层次上。

segments.en: And now for the last phrase, I'm putting it together.
segments.cn: 现在最后一个短语，我把它放在一起。

segments.en: He said you go take care of business to take care of business.
Okay, so I have to take care of business.
segments.cn: 好的，所以我得处理事务。

segments.en: So we're not really talking about business and work here.
segments.cn: 所以我们并不是在谈论商业和工作。

segments.en: So basically what we're saying is go handle your affairs.
segments.cn: 所以基本上我们在说去处理你的事务。

segments.en: So do the things you have to do.
segments.cn: 所以做你必须做的事情。

segments.en: Okay, so or solve your problem.
segments.cn: 好的，或者解决你的问题。

segments.en: So if I say I have to go to City Hall today and take care of some business.
segments.cn: 所以如果我说我今天得去市政厅处理一些事务。

segments.en: So you're maybe going to do something like pay my taxes or something like that.
segments.cn: 所以你可能要做一些像缴税之类的事情。

segments.en: Okay, so to take care of business.
Okay, so we heard some great phrases.
segments.cn: 好的，我们听到了一些很好的短语。

segments.en: Let's listen to the dialogue for the last time and then we'll come back and talk about this great decade.
segments.cn: 让我们最后再听一次对话，然后我们再回来谈谈这个伟大的十年。

segments.en: Hey, man, I really like your pad.
segments.cn: 嘿，兄弟，我真的很喜欢你的地方。

segments.en: Those lava lamps are far out.
Thanks for letting me crash here tonight.
segments.cn: 谢谢你今晚让我在这里过夜。

segments.en: I wanted a pad where people could come listen to music and just hang loose.
segments.cn: 我想要一个人们可以来听音乐和放松的地方。

segments.en: We should throw a bash here and make it really happening scene.
segments.cn: 我们应该在这里举办一个派对，让它变得热闹。

segments.en: Yeah, man, that would be groovy.
Hey, I got a split for a while.
Are you okay here by yourself?
segments.cn: 你一个人在这里还好吗？

segments.en: You can take care of your business.
segments.cn: 你可以去处理你的事务。

segments.en: All right, so 1960s, very famous among rock music, the peace and conflicts and all this stuff.
segments.cn: 好的，所以1960年代，在摇滚音乐、和平与冲突等方面非常著名。

segments.en: And I guess in in English or Anglo pop culture, we look back at this decade very fondly.
segments.cn: 我想在英语或英美流行文化中，我们非常怀念这个十年。

segments.en: And also we really related to the hippie movement.
segments.cn: 我们也与嬉皮士运动有很大的关联。

segments.en: People with long hair and baggy clothes and you know, living in their cars going from concert to concert.
segments.cn: 长发和宽松衣服的人，你知道的，住在车里，从一个音乐会到另一个音乐会。

segments.en: And I mean, speaking of music, I think if we think 1960s, at least in Anglo world, in the Anglo world, we think of the best music.
segments.cn: 说到音乐，我认为如果我们想到1960年代，至少在英美世界，我们会想到最好的音乐。

segments.en: Like, I think this is the golden age of music in English-speaking country.
segments.cn: 我认为这是英语国家音乐的黄金时代。

segments.en: Yes, it was a very good era.
segments.cn: 是的，那是一个非常好的时代。

segments.en: And well, what do you guys think?
Do you think the 60s was the best decade or maybe you are more fond of the 70s, the disco era?
segments.cn: 你认为60年代是最好的十年，还是你更喜欢70年代，迪斯科时代？

segments.en: There's some pretty good music in 1994.
So come to our website and let us know what you think.
segments.cn: 所以来我们的网站告诉我们你的想法。

segments.en: And also if you have any questions or comments.
segments.cn: 如果你有任何问题或评论，也请告诉我们。

segments.en: Marco and I are always around to answer your questions.
segments.cn: 马尔科和我随时可以回答你的问题。

segments.en: So thanks for downloading and until next time.
segments.cn: 所以谢谢你下载，直到下次见。
